Stragglers Are Not Disaster: A Hybrid Federated Learning Algorithm with Delayed Gradients

Abstract

Federated learning (FL) is a new machine learning framework which trains a joint model across a large amount of decentralized computing devices. Existing methods, e.g., Federated Averaging (FedAvg), are able to provide an optimization guarantee by synchronously training the joint model, but usually suffer from stragglers, i.e., IoT devices with low computing power or communication bandwidth, especially on heterogeneous optimization problems. To mitigate the influence of stragglers, this paper presents a novel FL algorithm, namely Hybrid Federated Learning (HFL), to achieve a learning balance in efficiency and effectiveness. It consists of two major components: synchronous kernel and asynchronous updater. Unlike traditional synchronous FL methods, our HFL introduces the asynchronous updater which actively pulls unsynchronized and delayed local weights from stragglers. An adaptive approximation method, Adaptive Delayed-SGD (AD-SGD), is proposed to merge the delayed local updates into the joint model. The theoretical analysis of HFL shows that the convergence rate of the proposed algorithm is ğ’ªâ€‹(1t+Ï„)ğ’ª1ğ‘¡ğœ\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{t+\tau}) for both convex and non-convex optimization problems.

1 Introduction

Federated Learning (FL) KoneÄná»³ etÂ al. (2016), has emerged as an attractive paradigm for training a joint model in a federated network. Compared to the standard parallel optimization framework where the model is trained with the large-scaled dataset on a central server Shalev-Shwartz & Ben-David (2014); Goodfellow etÂ al. (2016), FL trains a joint model under the coordination of a server across a large number remote devices. The joint model is learned with the updates from the remote devices via local training on their private data Johansson etÂ al. (2007); Lee & Nedic (2013); Bonawitz etÂ al. (2017); McMahan etÂ al. (2017). Since the model is trained without sharing data, the data privacy can be greatly enhanced in FL.

Two key challenges arise in FL. First, FL typically trains the model on a heterogeneous network, where the remote devices are large in number and have a variety of computing power and communication bandwidth. This makes the training process suffer from many stragglers which are slow in their local model training. Second, FL usually trains on a heterogeneous dataset, where training data are highly unbalanced and non-i.i.d. To tackle these challenges, several FL frameworks have been studied in literature. For example, Federated Averaging (FedAvg) McMahan etÂ al. (2017) is developed to address the communication constraint by performing multiple local learning steps on a subset of remote devices before uploading the model updates into the server.

The convergence of FedAvg can be guaranteed Li etÂ al. (2019) when the following two assumptions are made: (i) during the learning process, all remote devices are active, and (ii) the server can access all remote devices with equal probabilities. Later works following the first assumption Zhou & Cong (2017); Li etÂ al. (2019); Woodworth etÂ al. (2018); Wang etÂ al. (2019); Yu etÂ al. (2019) and following these two assumptions Stich (2018); Li etÂ al. (2019); Khaled etÂ al. (2020); Karimireddy etÂ al. (2020); Qu etÂ al. (2020); Yang etÂ al. (2021) have been conducted to further improve FL performance. However, these two assumptions usually do not hold in practical FL applications, due to the fact that straggles would commonly exist in the network. Once the straggler has the same possibility to be chosen by the server, the learning speed will be greatly reduced. Moreover, the data heterogeneity of FL tells that these stragglers could not be excluded from the training process, as they may contain unique local data that could not be found in other devices.

In this paper, we propose a new FL algorithm, called Hybrid Federated Learning (HFL), to enhance the learning performance of FL with the presence of stragglers in the network. The proposed HFL has two key components: a synchronous kernel and an asynchronous updater for two different communication scenarios. The synchronous kernel aims to synchronize those devices (i.e., non-stragglers) that have high enough computation and communication capacities, and performs the same training strategy as FedAvg which synchronously communicates with the selected devices in every communication round. The asynchronous updater aims to incorporate model updates of those stragglers, which could be several steps behind the synchronous kernel, into the joint model training process. Moreover, to bridge the gap between the delayed gradients and the optimal gradients from stragglers, we develop an adaptive approximation method called Adaptive Delayed-SGD (AD-SGD). In particular, the proposed AD-SGD first applies the Taylor expansion to approximate the optimal gradient of a straggler from its delayed gradients in a distributed network. Meanwhile, an adaptive hyper-parameter controlling mechanism is developed to reduce the bias of Taylor series approximation.

We evaluate our proposed HFL algorithm through both theoretical analysis and comprehensive experiments. On both convex and non-convex optimization problems, we provide the theoretical convergence guarantee with non-i.i.d distributed data. The discussion of the convergence rate of HFL is also provided. The experimental results show that HFL outperforms existing FL algorithms. In summary, the contribution of this paper are as follows

  • â€¢

    To address the learning of heterogeneous data in FL network with stragglers, we propose a hybrid structured algorithm HFL consisting of a synchronous kernel and an asynchronous updater to jointly train the model, enabling a learning balance in efficiency and effectiveness.

  • â€¢

    To obtain the optimal joint model, we develop an adaptive approximation method AD-SGD to bridge the gap between the delayed gradients and the optimal gradients.

  • â€¢

    We show the performance of theoretical analysis and experiments, which guarantees a convergence on both convex and non-convex optimization problems.

Paper organization. In SectionÂ 2, we describe the background of HFL. In SectionÂ 3, we detail our proposed HFL algorithm. In SectionÂ 4, we provide theoretical analysis on the convergence rate of HFL. In SectionÂ 5, we provide experimental results and analysis by comparing HFL with existing algorithms. For the supplementary material, we introduce the related works in SectionÂ A, the detailed demonstration of convergence results in SectionÂ B and the extended experiment settings and results in SectionÂ C.

2 Background

2.1 FL Objective

Consider a distributed network which has one central server and Nğ‘N remote devices. Each remote device owns its local private dataset ğ—isuperscriptğ—ğ‘–\mathbf{X}^{i}, for i=1,2,â‹¯,Nğ‘–12â‹¯ğ‘i=1,2,\cdots,N. In this paper, we consider the local data are non-i.i.d., i.e., the data distributions for any two remote devices can be different. A FL process starts with an initialization of a model in the server, and iteratively performs local model training in individual remote devices and joint model updating in the server. 2.2 Design Motivation

It is desired to have all remote devices participating the training process, in order to achieve the optimal performance in solving EquationÂ (1). However, the presence of stragglers in the distributed network will significantly reduce the training speed of existing synchronous FL methods which is actually determined by the slowest device.

To reduce the impact of stragglers, some prior studies Stich (2018); Li etÂ al. (2019); Karimireddy etÂ al. (2020); Yang etÂ al. (2021) have been taken and provide a partial participation algorithm: a threshold Kâ€‹(1â‰¤Kâ‰¤N)ğ¾1ğ¾ğ‘K(1\leq K\leq N) is empirically selected so that the server only accepts model updates from the first Kğ¾K remote devices while discarding the rest Nâˆ’Kğ‘ğ¾N-K slow participators regarded as stragglers. By doing so, the bottleneck of stragglers can be avoided by simply excluding them from the training process. However, due to the data heterogeneity of FL, the removal of those stragglers can greatly reduce the learning performance. Hence, the presence of stragglers in FL usually causes the dilemma ofâ€œ efficiency-effectivenessâ€ in learning.

To achieve a balance in learning efficiency and effectiveness, it is necessary to incorporate model updates from stragglers without incurring a long waiting time for synchronization in the server. This motivates us to develop a hybrid learning framework in which both synchronous learning for normal devices and asynchronous learning for slow devices (i.e., stragglers) are considered. However, the incorporation of the delayed model updates from stragglers into the joint model in the server should be carefully designed, which is detailed in the next section.

3 Hybrid Federated Learning

3.1 Outline

The server in our proposed HFL divides its connected remote devices into two categories: normal devices and stragglers, based on their communication and computation performance. This can be typically done by analyzing their historical behaviors. We denote the set of normal devices by ğ’®1subscriptğ’®1\mathcal{S}_{1} and the set of stragglers by ğ’®2subscriptğ’®2\mathcal{S}_{2}, where |ğ’®1|+|ğ’®2|=Nsubscriptğ’®1subscriptğ’®2ğ‘|\mathcal{S}_{1}|+|\mathcal{S}_{2}|=N. Hence, the HFL consists of two components: synchronous kernel which communicates with the normal devices in each communication round, and the asynchronous updater which incorporates delayed model updates (i.e., neural network gradients) from stragglers.

Similar to existing synchronous FL methods McMahan etÂ al. (2017); KoneÄná»³ etÂ al. (2016); Li etÂ al. (2019), we perform model update of the synchronous kernel as a weighted summation of a sequence of local updates. For each straggler, we use Ï„isubscriptğœğ‘–\tau_{i}, iâˆˆğ’®2ğ‘–subscriptğ’®2i\in\mathcal{S}_{2}, to indicate the number of rounds behind to the current sequence. Especially, we have Ï„i=0subscriptğœğ‘–0\tau_{i}=0, iâˆˆğ’®1ğ‘–subscriptğ’®1i\in\mathcal{S}_{1}, for normal devices. Then, the current joint model with both the synchronous kernel and the asynchronous updater would be

ğ°t={âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®1piâ€‹ğ°tiifÂ â€‹tâ‰¤maxiâˆˆğ’®2â¡Ï„iâˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®1piâ€‹ğ°ti+âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®2piâ€‹ğ°tâˆ’Ï„iiOtherwisesubscriptğ°ğ‘¡casessubscriptğ‘–subscriptğ’®1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ°ğ‘–ğ‘¡ifÂ ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ’®2subscriptğœğ‘–subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ’®1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ°ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ’®2subscriptğ‘ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘¡subscriptğœğ‘–ğ‘–Otherwise\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{t}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{cc}\sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{S}_{1}}p_{i}\mathbf{w}^{i}_{t}&\text{if }t\leq\max\limits_{i\in\mathcal{S}_{2}}\tau_{i}\\ \sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{S}_{1}}p_{i}\mathbf{w}^{i}_{t}+\sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{S}_{2}}p_{i}\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau_{i}}^{i}&\text{Otherwise}\\ \end{array}\right. (6)

FigureÂ 1 illustrates the joint learning process of the proposed HFL using both synchronous kernel and asynchronous updater with the presence of stragglers, where only one normal device and two stragglers are only given as an example. At t=0ğ‘¡0t=0, the server initializes a joint model and broadcasts it to all devices. At t=1ğ‘¡1t=1, only the normal device completes local training and return its model updates to the server for synchronously updating the joint model, handled by the synchronous kernel. At t=2ğ‘¡2t=2 and t=3ğ‘¡3t=3, when a straggler completes its local training, the asynchronous updater can incorporate the delayed model updates to the joint model.

It is clear that the main challenge is how to utilize the delayed model updates to contribute the training of the current joint model. The shown updating mechanism in EquationÂ (6) is problematic in that at the tğ‘¡t-th communication round, the iğ‘–i-th straggler actually sends back a delayed gradient gâ€‹(ğ°tâˆ’Ï„i)ğ‘”superscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœğ‘–g(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau}^{i}). To reach the optimal solution of ğ°tsubscriptğ°ğ‘¡\mathbf{w}_{t}, we need to approach the â€œup-to-dateâ€ gradient gâ€‹(ğ°ti)ğ‘”superscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ‘–g(\mathbf{w}_{t}^{i}) from gâ€‹(ğ°tâˆ’Ï„i)ğ‘”superscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœğ‘–g(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau}^{i}), which is a well-known problem in asynchronous SGD optimization field Stich & Karimireddy (2019); Arjevani etÂ al. (2020); Glasgow & Wootters (2020). In addition, stragglers in a FL network can have a variety of computation power, which leads to a highly unbalanced distribution of Ï„ğœ\tau. Thus, in this paper, we develop an adaptive approximation solution to address this problem.

3.2 Adaptive Delayed-SGD (AD-SGD)

In order to bridge the gap between the gradient from the joint model gâ€‹(ğ°ti)ğ‘”superscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ‘–g(\mathbf{w}_{t}^{i}) to the delayed gradient gâ€‹(ğ°tâˆ’Ï„i)ğ‘”superscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœğ‘–g(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau}^{i}), we propose a novel adaptive approximation method. For simplicity, when there is no confusion, we omit the index iğ‘–i in the rest of this paper for presentation purpose.

Taylor Expansion. We apply the Taylor expansion Folland (2005); Bischof etÂ al. (1993) to expand the gradient update gâ€‹(ğ°t)ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡g(\mathbf{w}_{t}) for the current joint model at the (tâˆ’Ï„)ğ‘¡ğœ(t-\tau)-th step as follows

where Insubscriptğ¼ğ‘›I_{n} is a nğ‘›n-dimension all-ones vector, and âˆ‡gâ€‹(â‹…)âˆ‡ğ‘”â‹…\nabla g(\cdot) represents a gradient matrix, whose element gi,j=âˆ‚â„’2âˆ‚wiâ€‹âˆ‚wjsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptâ„’2subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘—g_{i,j}=\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}^{2}}{\partial w_{i}\partial w_{j}} for i,jâˆˆnğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘›i,j\in n. Note that gâ€‹(ğ°tâˆ’Ï„)ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœg(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau}) is the zero-order item in the Taylor expansion of gâ€‹(ğ°t)ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡g(\mathbf{w}_{t}) and the major difference between the expected model gradient gâ€‹(ğ°t)ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡g(\mathbf{w}_{t}) and the delayed model gradient gâ€‹(ğ°tâˆ’Ï„)ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœg(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau}) comes from the higher-order components âˆ‡gâ€‹(ğ°tâˆ’Ï„)â€‹(ğ°tâˆ’ğ°tâˆ’Ï„)+ğ’ªâ€‹((ğ°tâˆ’ğ°tâˆ’Ï„)2)â€‹Inâˆ‡ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœsubscriptğ°ğ‘¡subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœğ’ªsuperscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘¡subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœ2subscriptğ¼ğ‘›\nabla g(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau})(\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau})+\mathcal{O}((\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau})^{2})I_{n}. Intuitively, we could use the full Taylor expansion in EquationÂ (7) to approach gâ€‹(ğ°t)ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡g(\mathbf{w}_{t}), however, this is unrealistic due to its high computation cost. Additionally, even solving the first-order item âˆ‡gâ€‹(ğ°tâˆ’Ï„)â€‹(ğ°tâˆ’ğ°tâˆ’Ï„)âˆ‡ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœsubscriptğ°ğ‘¡subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœ\nabla g(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau})(\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau}) is also highly non-trivial, which is considered to be the Hessian matrix Hâ€‹(ğ°tâˆ’Ï„)ğ»subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœH(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau}) of the joint loss function.

Approximation of Hessian Matrix. Since the computation cost of the Hessian matrix in the FL network is still expensive, we consider an alternative approach to address this problem with a limited computational resource.

In particular, we use the gradient of the joint model gâ€‹(ğ°tâˆ’Ï„)ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœg(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau}) computed during the local training process. An outer product matrix Râ€‹(ğ°tâˆ’Ï„)âˆˆâ„nÃ—nğ‘…subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘›R(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau})\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times n} can be obtained with gâ€‹(ğ°tâˆ’Ï„)ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœg(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau}) at the (tâˆ’Ï„)ğ‘¡ğœ(t-\tau)-th communication round as

Râ€‹(ğ°tâˆ’Ï„)=(âˆ‚âˆ‚ğ°â€‹â„’â€‹(ğ°tâˆ’Ï„;ğ—))â€‹(âˆ‚âˆ‚ğ°â€‹â„’â€‹(ğ°tâˆ’Ï„;ğ—))âŠ¤.ğ‘…subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœğ°â„’subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœğ—superscriptğ°â„’subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœğ—topR(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau})=\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial\mathbf{w}}\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau};\mathbf{X})\right)\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial\mathbf{w}}\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau};\mathbf{X})\right)^{\top}. (8)

It can be seen that the outer product matrix Râ€‹(ğ°tâˆ’Ï„)ğ‘…subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœR(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau}) and the Hessian matrix Hâ€‹(ğ°tâˆ’Ï„)ğ»subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœ{H}(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau}) are two equivalent methods to calculate the fisher information matrix Friedman etÂ al. (2001), because the cross entropy loss in this case is a negative log-likelihood with respect to the softmax function. This equivalent approach for solving the Hessian matrix has been applied in the recent works Choromanska etÂ al. (2015); Kawaguchi (2016). Thus, from the already computed gradients, we obtain an alternate approximation method to the Hessian matrix by the outer production.

Adaptive Hyper-parameter. Using the gradient outer product to approximate the Hessian matrix, the optimal gradient gâ€‹(ğ°t)ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡g(\mathbf{w}_{t}) could be represented as follows

gâ€‹(ğ°t)=gâ€‹(ğ°tâˆ’Ï„)+Râ€‹(ğ°tâˆ’Ï„)â€‹(ğ°tâˆ’ğ°tâˆ’Ï„).ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœğ‘…subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœsubscriptğ°ğ‘¡subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœg(\mathbf{w}_{t})=g(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau})+R(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau})(\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau}). (9)

However, this approximation still could still a large error from the omitted high-order items ğ’ª((ğ°t)âˆ’ğ°tâˆ’Ï„)2)In\mathcal{O}((\mathbf{w}_{t})-\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau})^{2})I_{n} in the Taylor expansion, especially with a large delay Ï„ğœ\tau, which is common in FL network settings. Thus, in order to reduce the impact from different stragglers, we introduce an adaptive hyper-parameter to control the weight of our approximation into the joint model aggregation, which is related to the value of Ï„ğœ\tau and the training round tğ‘¡t. The main idea is that a slower straggler (i.e., a larger Ï„ğœ\tau) contributes less into the joint model training, and this contribution continuously decreases when communication round increasing (i.e., tğ‘¡t) in order to reduce oscillation when the learning converges. In particular, our AD-SGD method introduces a hyper-parameter Î»tsubscriptğœ†ğ‘¡\lambda_{t} with an exponential decay function on tğ‘¡t and Ï„ğœ\tau as follows

Î»t=Î»0â€‹expâ¡(âˆ’(tâˆ’Ï„)).subscriptğœ†ğ‘¡subscriptğœ†0ğ‘¡ğœ\lambda_{t}=\lambda_{0}\exp(-(t-\tau)). (10)

where Î»0subscriptğœ†0\lambda_{0} is a user-defined parameter. While its optimal value can be determined through cross validation, a constant value of Î»0=0.5subscriptğœ†00.5\lambda_{0}=0.5 is used in our experiments. The choice of Î»0subscriptğœ†0\lambda_{0} in our HFL algorithm will also be discussed in detail with experimental results in Section.Â 5.2.

Therefore, using the AD-SGD method, the joint model update for our HFL algorithm in EquationÂ (6) can be given

ğ°t=(1âˆ’Î»t)â€‹ğ°^t+Î»tâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®2piâ€‹(ğ°tâˆ’Ï„iiâˆ’Î·tâ€‹gâ€‹(ğ°ti)),subscriptğ°ğ‘¡1subscriptğœ†ğ‘¡subscript^ğ°ğ‘¡subscriptğœ†ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ’®2subscriptğ‘ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘¡subscriptğœğ‘–ğ‘–subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡ğ‘”superscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ‘–\mathbf{w}_{t}=(1-\lambda_{t})\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{t}+\lambda_{t}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}_{2}}p_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau_{i}}^{i}-\eta_{t}g(\mathbf{w}_{t}^{i})), (11)

where gâ€‹(ğ°ti)ğ‘”superscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ‘–g(\mathbf{w}_{t}^{i}) is approximated from the outer product matrix as gâ€‹(ğ°ti)=gâ€‹(ğ°tâˆ’Ï„ii)+Râ€‹(ğ°tâˆ’Ï„ii)â€‹(ğ°tiâˆ’ğ°tâˆ’Ï„ii).ğ‘”superscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘”superscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘¡subscriptğœğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘…superscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘¡subscriptğœğ‘–ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘¡subscriptğœğ‘–ğ‘–g(\mathbf{w}_{t}^{i})=g(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau_{i}}^{i})+R(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau_{i}}^{i})({\mathbf{w}}_{t}^{i}-\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau_{i}}^{i}).

3.3 Algorithm Description

To this end, we use the AD-SGD method to bridge the gap between the delayed gradients and the optimal gradients for stragglers in FL. In particular, we approximate the Hessian matrix using the outer product gradient with a low computation cost, which have been proved to be equivalent for the calculation of the Fisher information matrix. With the help of AD-SGD, we are able to achieve a learning balance in efficiency and effectiveness when stragglers are present in FL. Specifically, we summarize the proposed HFL algorithm in AlgorithmÂ 1 and 2, where AlgorithmÂ 1 introduces the local learning process and AlgorithmÂ 2 shows the joint model updating mechanism.

According to AlgorithmÂ 1, at the tğ‘¡t-th round, the iğ‘–i-th remote device receives the current joint model ğ°tsubscriptğ°ğ‘¡\mathbf{w}_{t} from the server, performs the local training process with Eğ¸E epochs and sends model updates back to the server at the (t+Ï„i)ğ‘¡subscriptğœğ‘–(t+\tau_{i})-th round with various delays for stragglers (Ï„iâ‰¥0subscriptğœğ‘–0\tau_{i}\geq 0). And for the server side, unlike existing FL methods, the server stores a backup model at the tğ‘¡t-th round when the straggler receives the joint model. When the delayed gradient gâ€‹(ğ°t+Ï„ii)ğ‘”superscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘¡subscriptğœğ‘–ğ‘–g(\mathbf{w}_{t+\tau_{i}}^{i}) is received by the server at the (t+Ï„)ğ‘¡ğœ(t+\tau)-th round, the server updates the joint model based on the updating rule using EquationÂ (11).

Note that compared to existing synchronous FL algorithms, e.g., FedAvg, there is no extra communication rounds and extra remote device computational requirement in our HFL. In particular, the approximation cost from the EquationÂ (11) mainly comes from the additional storage of several previous joint models on the server. The backup of the previous joint model does not violate the privacy settings of the FL network.

4 Convergence Analysis

In this section, we provide the convergence analysis of the proposed HFL algorithm with the adaptive approximation method AD-SGD for the delayed gradients. In this paper, both the convex and non-convex optimization problems are investigated. Due to the space limitation, we only provide the results and leave the detailed proof to the supplementary materials in SectionÂ B.

5 Experiments

5.1 Experimental Setup

Models and Datasets. To evaluate the performance of the proposed HFL algorithm, we conduct experiments on multiple datasets for both convex and non-convex optimization problems. For convex optimization, we design experiments with logistic regression models on the Fashion MNIST Xiao etÂ al. (2017) and a synthetic dataset. We distribute training samples to different remote devices following the power law distribution to obtain non-i.i.d distributed learning data. The synthetic dataset is generated in the same way as presented in previous studies Li etÂ al. (2019), which is easy to be manipulated for controlling data heterogeneity. We denote it as Sâ€‹yâ€‹nâ€‹tâ€‹hâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹iâ€‹câ€‹(Î³,Î¾)ğ‘†ğ‘¦ğ‘›ğ‘¡â„ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘ğ›¾ğœ‰Synthetic(\gamma,\xi), where Î³ğ›¾\gamma controls the difference between any two local models and Î¾ğœ‰\xi controls how much difference between the learning data in each device. For non-convex optimization, we select Sentiment140 (Sent140) Go etÂ al. (2009) and The Complete Works of William Shakespeare (Shakespeare) McMahan etÂ al. (2017) with a LSTM classifier.

Experimental Settings. All experiments are conducted in a distributed network that consists of N=100ğ‘100N=100 devices. The total number of global communication is T=200ğ‘‡200T=200 and the number of local epochs is E=5ğ¸5E=5. The maximum value of Ï„ğœ\tau is set to 101010 and Ï„iâˆˆğ’®2subscriptğœğ‘–subscriptğ’®2\tau_{i}\in\mathcal{S}_{2} are uniformly distributed. The following methods are used for comparison:

1) Sequential SGD (S-SGD) Zinkevich etÂ al. (2010). We implement the standard S-SGD in a centralized environment. Therefore, this method provides the upper bound performance over all compared methods in this paper.

2) FedAvg. FedAvg is considered as one of the groundbreaking works in FL research field. We setup the FedAvg algorithm based on the settings in Li etÂ al. (2019), which provides a convergence guarantee against non-i.i.d. data problems. In particular, we set the possibility for the server to the remote devices corresponding to a normalized vector that pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–p_{i} is linear to Ï„isubscriptğœğ‘–\tau_{i}. The value of Kğ¾K for the number of selected devices in each communication round is set to 101010 by default.

3) FedProx Sahu etÂ al. (2018). FedProx is one popular variant of FedAvg which adds a quadratic proximal term to limit the impact from local updates in a heterogeneous network. In this paper, we follow the instructions provided in the original paper to evaluate the performance with 90%percent9090\% stragglers and the same remote devices possibility distribution in FedAvg.

Implementations. we define the joint model initialization ğ°0=0subscriptğ°00\mathbf{w}_{0}=0 and the initial learning rate Î·0=0.1subscriptğœ‚00.1\eta_{0}=0.1 with a decay function Î·t=Î·01+tsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğœ‚01ğ‘¡\eta_{t}=\frac{\eta_{0}}{1+t}. In each local training step, we consider that the remote device use SGD to train local model with its all local training data and with a batch size of 646464. For the delayed gradients in EquationÂ (10), we set Î»0=0.5subscriptğœ†00.5\lambda_{0}=0.5.

5.2 Convex Optimization Results

Comparison to benchmarks. In Figure.Â 2, we compare learning performance for the convex optimization on both synthetic and Fashion MNIST datasets with logistic regression. The results show that our HFL algorithm achieves the best overall testing accuracy compared to other methods. For the Fashion MNIST dataset, it can be seen that the upper bound testing accuracy for Fashion MNIST using the S-SGD method is 84.58%percent84.5884.58\% and our HFL reaches 83.41%percent83.4183.41\% testing accuracy. Meanwhile, the converged accuracy for FedAvg is only 71.92%percent71.9271.92\% and 75.49%percent75.4975.49\% for FedProx. Note that the learning curve of HFL contains some obvious oscillations, which mainly comes from the approximation of the optimal model from delayed gradients. We can also notice that as the learning steps tğ‘¡t grows, the amplitude of the oscillation becomes smaller, which is mainly due to the use of our AD-SGD method that can reduce the impact of delayed gradients in an adaptive way.

For Synthetic dataset, we evaluate the performance of HFL under two Î³ğ›¾\gamma and Î¾ğœ‰\xi settings, i.e., Sâ€‹yâ€‹nâ€‹tâ€‹hâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹iâ€‹câ€‹(0,0)ğ‘†ğ‘¦ğ‘›ğ‘¡â„ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘00Synthetic(0,0) and Sâ€‹yâ€‹nâ€‹tâ€‹hâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹iâ€‹câ€‹(1,1)ğ‘†ğ‘¦ğ‘›ğ‘¡â„ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘11Synthetic(1,1). The results are shown in FiguresÂ 2(b)-2(c). We could notice that compared to the results in the Fashion MNIST dataset, the performance improvement of HFL is greater than other methods on both two synthetic datasets. Meanwhile, the convergence rate of HFL is slower in Sâ€‹yâ€‹nâ€‹tâ€‹hâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹iâ€‹câ€‹(1,1)ğ‘†ğ‘¦ğ‘›ğ‘¡â„ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘11Synthetic(1,1) than Sâ€‹yâ€‹nâ€‹tâ€‹hâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹iâ€‹câ€‹(0,0)ğ‘†ğ‘¦ğ‘›ğ‘¡â„ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘00Synthetic(0,0). The reason might be that an increasing data heterogeneity can make the convergence rate more dependent the delayed value Ï„ğœ\tau.

Choice of Î»0subscriptğœ†0\lambda_{0}. Here, we evaluate the choice of Î»0subscriptğœ†0\lambda_{0} to the performance of HFL. We set the value of Î»0subscriptğœ†0\lambda_{0} from 0.10.10.1 to 0.90.90.9 on the Fashion MNIST dataset with a fixed communication round T=200ğ‘‡200T=200, and the results are shown in Figure.Â 3. It can be seen that when Î»0=0.5,subscriptğœ†00.5\lambda_{0}=0.5, HFL has the best the testing accuracy and the training loss, and the testing accuracy results with different Î»0subscriptğœ†0\lambda_{0} ranging from 0.10.10.1 to 0.90.90.9 has a symmetrical pattern with the mean value at 0.50.50.5. Additionally, we examine the largest difference of the testing accuracy in this setting with different values of Î»0subscriptğœ†0\lambda_{0} is only 0.4%percent0.40.4\%, which indicates that our algorithm might be adaptive to the setting of Î»0subscriptğœ†0\lambda_{0} during the training process of HFL.

Choice of Ï„ğœ\tau. In SecÂ 4, our discussion suggests that the convergence rate of HFL can be influenced by the choice of Ï„ğœ\tau. We investigate this case on the Fashion MNIST dataset with different maximum Ï„ğœ\tau values, followed by a fixed communication round T=200ğ‘‡200T=200. The results in FigureÂ 4 come with maximum Ï„âˆˆ[10,100]ğœ10100\tau\in[10,100] and Ï„i,iâˆˆğ’®2subscriptğœğ‘–ğ‘–subscriptğ’®2\tau_{i},i\in\mathcal{S}_{2} is uniformly distributed. We could notice when Ï„=10,ğœ10\tau=10, both the testing accuracy and the training loss have the best performance. However, we find an interesting phenomenon that when Ï„=40,50ğœ4050\tau=40,50 and 606060, learning performance is significantly better than other settings. We consider the reason of this phenomenon might indicate a non-linear relationship between the setting of Ï„ğœ\tau and the optimization performance, and this could be a interesting topic for our further research.

5.3 Non-convex Optimization Results

We then evaluate the performance of our HFL algorithm on non-convex optimization problems. The comparison results for HFL against existing FL methods on Sent140140140 and Shakespeare datasets to train a LSTM classifier are provided. The results in FiguresÂ 5(a) and 5(b) show that our HFL algorithm has the best overall testing accuracy and training loss against existing FL algorithms on Sent140. In particular, the results in FigureÂ 5(a) show that, although HFL has a slower convergence rate compared to FedAvg and FedProx, the testing accuracy is significantly higher. Although there are notable oscillations in the training process of our HFL, we consider it could be tolerated by comparing the amplitude of the oscillation to other FL algorithms.

The results in FiguresÂ 5(c)-5(d) show the comparison on the Shakespeare dataset. From the results, we can see that, compared to the FedAvg and the FedProx, HFL obtains has an improved testing accuracy and training loss. Although the results show a clear gap between HFL and S-SGD method and the convergence rate of HFL is slow in this dataset, HFL still outperforms FedAvg and FedProx with a non-overfitting training loss and at least 12%percent1212\% higher testing accuracy. In conclusion, we believe the proposed HFL algorithm has a better performance against other FL methods for solving non-convex optimization problems.

6 Conclusion

In this paper, we investigated the impact of stragglers on the performance of non-i.i.d. optimization in a heterogeneous network for FL. We proposed a new FL algorithm, called HFL, with two key components: a synchronous kernel and an asynchronous updater to train the joint model under two difference communication scenarios. To incorporate delayed local gradients from stragglers, we designed an adaptive approximation method, called AD-SGD. We demonstrated the effectiveness of HFL through theoretical convergence analysis and experimental evaluations. Theoretically, we provided the convergence guarantee of our HFL on both convex and non-convex optimization problems in heterogeneous network, followed by a discussion on the convergence learning rate. Empirically, we showed that HFL outperforms existing synchronous FL methods on both synthetic and real-world benchmarks.

Supplementary
Stragglers Are Not Disaster: A Hybrid Federated Learning Algorithm with Delayed Gradient

Appendix A Related Work

Federated learning. Federated Learning (FL) KoneÄná»³ etÂ al. (2016), is a novel collaborative learning model in a distributed network which is usually with a center server and multiple remote devices. As the development of distributed networks, FL has attracted great interest from the ML research field. In a FL network, a joint model is trained on the server with the dataset distributed among the remote devices. Specially, the training process of the FL model is without data sharing, which protects the data privacy in the network. The joint model is often trained to address distributed optimization problems, e.g., next word prediction Hard etÂ al. (2018); Yang etÂ al. (2018). Existing works on the FL mainly focus on the following categories: i) communication efficiency KoneÄná»³ etÂ al. (2016); McMahan etÂ al. (2017); Sahu etÂ al. (2018); Smith etÂ al. (2017); Li etÂ al. (2019); ii) distributed optimization problem Sattler etÂ al. (2019); Zhao etÂ al. (2018); Yan etÂ al. (2020) and iii) privacy consideration Baruch etÂ al. (2019); Fang etÂ al. (2019); Bhagoji etÂ al. (2019).

Heterogeneous optimization in FL. McMahan etÂ al. (2017) first proposes the SOTA Federated Averaging (FedAvg), which provides a convergence guarantee on the i.i.d optimization problems as well as being able to address the communication bottleneck of FL. By training the joint model with only a subset of devices in each communication round, instead of a full device participation scheme, FedAvg significantly increase the training speed of the joint model. Works from Sattler etÂ al. (2019); Zhao etÂ al. (2018) consider the optimization scenarios with non-i.i.d distributed learning data, however, the results in their works come without the convergence rate. Li etÂ al. (2019) investigate the FedAvg algorithm and provides a novel FedAvg mechanism to address non-i.i.d data optimization. A convergence guarantee is provided in Li etÂ al. (2019) with two assumptions: i) all the remote devices are active during the training process; ii) the server can randomly access each server in every communication round. To address the FL in a heterogeneous network, Sahu etÂ al. (2018) proposes FedProx, which is a popular variant of FedAvg with an added quadratic proximal term. This algorithm takes the statistical heterogeneity of the devices into consideration and gives a convergence guarantee on non-convex optimization problems under non-i.i.d settings. However, the existing works, e.g., FedAvg and FedProx, are both developed based on impractical assumptions that can violate the FL settings in real-world applications.

Appendix B Convergence Analysis of HFL

B.1 Convex Optimization

To introduce the convergence analysis of HFL against the convex optimization problems, we first introduce several extended assumptions, which have been applied in the previous FL convex optimization researches. In particular, the AssumptionÂ 4 and 5 have been made by the previous works Yu etÂ al. (2019); Stich (2018); Stich etÂ al. (2018) and the AssumptionÂ 3 is widely applied in existing works.

Assumption 3.

(Bounded local objective:) For the iii-th device at the ttt-th communication round, we consider the variance of the stochastic gradient against convex optimization problems in this local training process is uniformly bounded as

ğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°ti,ğ—ti)â€–2â‰¤Ïƒ2.ğ”¼superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ¹superscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ—ğ‘¡ğ‘–2superscriptğœ2\mathbb{E}||\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t}^{i},\mathbf{X}_{t}^{i})||^{2}\leq\sigma^{2}. (20)
Assumption 4.

(Î¼ğœ‡\mu-Quasi Convex): The objective function Fâ€‹(â‹…)ğ¹â‹…F(\cdot) for the FL network is differentiable and Î¼ğœ‡\mu-quasi convex with a constant value Î¼ğœ‡\mu that

Fâ€‹(ğ°â‹†)â‰¥Fâ€‹(ğ®)+âŸ¨ğ°â‹†âˆ’ğ®,âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ®)âŸ©+Î¼2â€‹â€–ğ°â‹†âˆ’ğ®â€–2,ğ¹superscriptğ°â‹†ğ¹ğ®superscriptğ°â‹†ğ®âˆ‡ğ¹ğ®ğœ‡2superscriptnormsuperscriptğ°â‹†ğ®2\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}^{\star})\geq F(\mathbf{u})+\langle\mathbf{w}^{\star}-\mathbf{u},\nabla F(\mathbf{u})\rangle+\frac{\mu}{2}{||\mathbf{w}^{\star}-\mathbf{u}||}^{2}, (21)

where ğ®ğ®\mathbf{u} represents an arbitrary weight status corresponding to the objectives.

Thus, we obtain the convergence rate for the HFL algorithm on non-convex problems as

Appendix C Experiments

C.1 Detailed Experimental Setting

Implementation. In this paper, we evaluate our HFL algorithm on multiple tasks, models and datasets in a simulated federated network. All the experiments are performed with Pytorch Paszke etÂ al. (2017) platform at version 1.6.01.6.01.6.0, and we represent the remote devices by lightweight threads with Python threading library. In order to simulate the asynchronous update process, we assign Ï„ğœ\tau-related flags to difference remote device threads.

Models. For the convex optimization problems, we evaluate our algorithm with a multinomial logistic regression model. We represent the prediction model as fâ€‹(ğ°;ğ±i)ğ‘“ğ°superscriptğ±ğ‘–f(\mathbf{w};\mathbf{x}^{i}) where ğ°=(ğ–,ğ›)ğ°ğ–ğ›\mathbf{w}=(\mathbf{W},\mathbf{b}), which satisfies fâ€‹(ğ°;ğ±i)=softmax(ğ–ğ±i+ğ›)ğ‘“ğ°superscriptğ±ğ‘–softmaxsuperscriptğ–ğ±ğ‘–ğ›f(\mathbf{w};\mathbf{x}^{i})=\operatorname*{softmax}(\mathbf{W}\mathbf{x}^{i}+\mathbf{b}). Then we have the loss function as

1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1NCrossEntropy(fâ€‹(ğ°;ğ±i))+Ïµâ€‹â€–ğ°â€–2,1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘CrossEntropyğ‘“ğ°superscriptğ±ğ‘–italic-Ïµsuperscriptnormğ°2\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\operatorname*{CrossEntropy}(f(\mathbf{w};\mathbf{x}^{i}))+\epsilon||\mathbf{w}||^{2},

where we define Ïµ=10âˆ’4italic-Ïµsuperscript104\epsilon=10^{-4} in this paper. And for the non-convex optimization problems, in this paper we introduce a LSTM classifier with a recurrent neural network (RNN) Zaremba etÂ al. (2014) architecture.

Datasets. In this part, we provide the full introduction of the datasets and the numerical information of datasets is summarized in TableÂ 2.

1) Synthetic Data. The synthetic data in this paper are developed followed by the original setup from the work in Shamir etÂ al. (2014); Li etÂ al. (2019), which is designed to simulate a quadratic problem. Specifically, for the iğ‘–i-th remote device, we generate the learning data samples (ğ±i,yi)superscriptğ±ğ‘–superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–(\mathbf{x}^{i},{y}^{i}) from a softmax function yi=argâ¡maxâ¡(sâ€‹oâ€‹fâ€‹tâ€‹mâ€‹aâ€‹xâ€‹(ğ°iâ€‹ğ±i+ğ›i))superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘œğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥superscriptğ°ğ‘–superscriptğ±ğ‘–superscriptğ›ğ‘–{y}^{i}=\arg\max(softmax(\mathbf{w}^{i}\mathbf{x}^{i}+\mathbf{b}^{i})), where we define ğ±iâˆˆâ„60superscriptğ±ğ‘–superscriptâ„60\mathbf{x}^{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{60}, ğ°iâˆˆâ„60Ã—10superscriptğ°ğ‘–superscriptâ„6010\mathbf{w}^{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{60\times 10} and ğ›iâˆˆâ„10superscriptğ›ğ‘–superscriptâ„10\mathbf{b}^{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{10}. In this situation, we use the parameters Î³ğ›¾\gamma and Î¾ğœ‰\xi to manipulate the heterogeneity of the synthetic dataset.

2) Fashion MNIST Xiao etÂ al. (2017). For the real dataset, we introduce Fashion MNIST in this paper as it has been popular among the ML research filed in the recent years. In order to build a non-i.i.d case, we consider each remote device only contains two labels of learning samples and to show the heterogeneity, we distribute the learning data from a power law.

3) Shakespeare McMahan etÂ al. (2017). The Shakespeare dataset is developed from â€œThe Complete Works of William Shakespeare McMahan etÂ al. (2017)â€. The task of this dataset is to predict the next-character from a input sequence. The number of characters(classes) is 808080 and the total number of input sequence is 517,106517106517,106.

4) Sent140 Go etÂ al. (2009). Sent140 is a text sentiment analysis dataset and popular in the non-convex problem experimental settings in the ML field. Sent140 provides a task to find to corresponding twitter account with a sequence of 252525 characters as input.

5) MNIST LeCun etÂ al. (1998). MNIST is a classic handwritten digits dataset from 00-999 for image classification problems. The data participation of MNIST in this paper follows the same setups in the Fashion MNIST and we use this dataset for extended evaluations in the supplementary material.
